rationale: Well-designed incentivized field experiment on cash vs in-kind with novel DWG finding and credible mechanisms (infra-marginality, commitment, bargaining). Strong analysis and robustness. Limits: single-city sample, constructed WTP bounds, few multiple-switchers, external validity. Policy-relevant and clearly written.

Main claims are precise and tied to experimental outcomes and regressions with controls and robustness. Good differentiation by headship and marginality. Some reliance on proxy for bargaining power; assignment for rice-only/cash-only WTP introduces assumptions but checked via sensitivity.

Incentive-compatible choice, clear sampling, repeated rounds, RE models with clustering and checks (bounds, interval regression). Exclusion of multiple-switchers reasonable but could bias; no preregistration; limited power for heterogeneity beyond headship; single locale.

Shifts discussion from presumed DWL to possible DWG via intra-household bargaining; offers practical insight for choice-based delivery. Adds to literature with incentivized WTP for in-kind. Novel in this context and likely to influence future work and pilots.
Clear motivation, theory link, transparent design and assumptions, figures/tables aid interpretation. Consistent conclusions. Minor complexity around constructed WTP is well explained.
Ethics approval and procedural detail are provided. However, no explicit data/code availability or preregistration noted. Replication possible with more materials, but current openness is limited.

Highly relevant to large-scale safety nets and cash vs in-kind debates in LMICs; directly informative for PDS-like programs and gender-sensitive design. External validity beyond one city is a caveat but policy insight is broad.

Ambitious, timely study combining preregistered online RCT with placebo and a very large field experiment linked to admin vote data. Clear effects, careful heterogeneity, and strong robustness. Direct policy relevance for persuasion under authoritarianism. Minor concerns: external validity beyond Türkiye; potential spillovers; limited individual-level outcomes in field.

Core claims are clearly stated and supported by experimental estimates with appropriate controls and placebo. Both self-reported and behavioral outcomes strengthen credibility. Multiple robustness checks and first-stage strength documented. Some residual risk of unobserved campaigning contamination and ballot-box aggregation.

Designs are well-justified; stratified randomization; 2SLS with neighborhood-level instruments; rich covariate sets; heteroskedasticity- and cluster-robust SEs; preregistration. Thoughtful placebo online. Minor limitations: neighborhood-level randomization may face interference; measurement of exposure via canvasser logs.

Novel evidence that accurate institutional information shifts votes in an authoritarian-leaning context, with effects concentrated among misinformed and regime supporters. Bridges literatures on persuasion, democratic support, and corruption/media. Scalable insights for practice. High contribution.

Clear theory of change, transparent exposition, figures and appendices helpful, limitations acknowledged. Minor density in some sections and many moving parts, but arguments remain coherent and conclusions proportionate to evidence.

IRB approvals and AEA registry cited; detailed online supplement and instruments. Admin electoral data are public. Full replication package and raw canvassing microdata may be constrained; not all materials/data availability is explicit in excerpt.

High salience for democracies under pressure; generalizable mechanisms for combating misinformation about institutions; practical implications for nonpartisan civic campaigns. Strong applicability beyond Türkiye with contextual caveats.

Large geo-randomized Facebook field experiment with high external validity, credible causal identification, and practical ROI analysis. Strong results on frequency and suggestive revenue gains; careful consideration of substitution and spillovers. Minor limitations: some revenue effects marginal, privacy limits on data sharing, Germany-specific context.

Core questions are clear; outcomes defined at PLZ-day with total donations across channels, reducing substitution bias. Frequency effects are precise; revenue effects weaker but consistent. Evidence on crowding out is suggestive to moderate. Robustness includes blocking, DiD, randomization inference, spillovers.

Geo-randomized blocking, preregistration, comprehensive outcomes, winsorization justified, multiple specs incl. DiD and RI. Sensible handling of spillovers and heterogeneity. Some reliance on p<0.1 for revenue, semi-aggregated platform metrics, and unavoidable privacy aggregation constraints.

Advances understanding of online fundraising effectiveness using nation-scale randomization, measures total donations, and documents substitution across charities. Offers actionable insights on targeting and algorithm allocation. Adds to literature beyond platform-only studies.

Clear structure, transparent assumptions, detailed design and outcome definitions, figures/tables informative. Links intermediate metrics to final outcomes and discusses managerial implications without overclaiming.

Preregistered design and extensive online appendix. However, individual-level data cannot be shared; PLZ-level data from partners likely restricted. Methods are replicable conceptually; full replication would require data access agreements.

High practical relevance for nonprofits and digital advertisers; cost-effectiveness estimates and targeting guidance. External validity strong within similar high-income contexts; policy relevance moderate for broader global priorities.

Strong, timely synthesis with clear modeling linking AI, automation, Baumol effects, and singularities. Credible authorship, careful framing, and useful agenda-setting. Limitations: largely theoretical with stylized simulations; limited empirical validation and reproducibility resources.

Claims are clearly scoped as exploratory; results follow from transparent assumptions. Evidence is primarily theoretical derivations and calibrated simulations; limited empirical tests and sensitivity to alternative mechanisms acknowledged but not fully explored.

Solid, well-grounded growth-theory modeling (task-based, CES, Schumpeterian variants) with logical consistency checks and parameter explorations. Some knife-edge cases noted. Robustness partly discussed; no formal estimation or preregistration; simulations illustrative.

Frames a coherent agenda on AI-growth; integrates automation, Baumol, idea production, and singularity scenarios; offers testable insights and sectoral angles. Influential for macro/innovation policy debates. High conceptual contribution despite limited empirics.

Clear structure, motivating questions, and derivations; intuitive exposition of mechanisms; figures aid understanding. Assumptions and limitations are explicit. Minor density in sections but overall highly readable for the target audience.

Working paper with equations and described simulations, but no shared code/data or replication package. Citations comprehensive. Reproducibility feasible for theorists yet not turn-key. Could improve with posted code and parameter files.

Directly relevant to macro growth, labor shares, automation policy, and AI governance. Offers frameworks for practitioners to anticipate sectoral and organizational impacts. Quantified policy estimates are limited; guidance is conceptual.

Ambitious, well-executed saturation RCT on seasonal migration with rich HF data, employer and shopkeeper modules, and clear GE analysis. Strong internal validity, coherent theory-empirics, practical insights. Some limitations on external validity and mixed significance for certain employer outcomes.

Main claims—emigration boosts migrant/non-migrant incomes, raises ag wages, modest price effects—are tightly linked to randomized variation and first-stage migration shocks. Multiple data sources triangulate. Some employer profit/yield results are imprecise; destination wage effects inferred indirectly.

Cluster saturation design, IV leveraging village intensity, HF panels minimize recall, multiple markets surveyed. Appropriate clustering and IV diagnostics. Some reliance on retrospective employer data; instruments weak in a few subsamples; assumptions on closed village labor markets reasonable but not ironclad.

Rare credible estimates of GE effects of internal migration subsidies; informs debates on labor surplus, policy toward seasonal migration, and spillovers. Extends prior work from partial to GE effects with policy salience.

Clear conceptual framework, transparent identification, thorough robustness, results organized logically. Tables and narrative connect mechanisms (complements in migration, wage and hours effects) convincingly.

Trial preregistered and design transparent. However, limited evidence here of public replication files or full data/code release at time of WP. Strong documentation but not exemplary on open materials.

High policy relevance for LMIC rural labor markets and migration programs; quantifies benefits and distributional effects. Direct implications for program scale-up and anti-migration policies. Context is Bangladesh; mechanisms plausibly broader.

Large-scale randomized Twitter campaign with credible identification of endorsement vs reach; solid online effects and suggestive offline impacts. Clear design and analyses. Some external validity and outcome limitations (self-reports; context-specific; mixed offline effects).

Main claims precisely stated and matched to experimental variation. Strong online causal evidence; offline results are framed as suggestive with appropriate caveats and robustness (RI p-values). Measurement limits for behavior acknowledged.

Thoughtful experimental design exploiting Twitter mechanics; within-celebrity randomization; Poisson models; clustering; fixed effects; forced-retweet checks; randomized phases with RI. Some risks: survey selection; self-reported network outcomes.

Separates endorsement from reach at scale; policy-relevant insights on sources and exposure shape. Advances diffusion literature with causal influencer evidence. Offline effects modest but informative.
Clear motivation, design schematics, transparent assumptions, limitations, and theory appendix. Results tied to questions; figures/tables support claims. Dense but coherent.

Trial preregistered; IRB noted. However, no clear public release of data/code in text; Twitter data access constraints. Moderate reproducibility given design clarity but limited raw data availability.
Public health messaging in LMIC; vaccination salience is high. Practical insights for campaigns. Generalizability to other platforms/contexts plausible but not guaranteed.

Innovative sufficient-statistics welfare framework for nudges with endogenous prices and taxes, plus two incentivized experiments estimating key heterogeneity moments. Strong theory-methods integration; careful discussion of limits. External validity and measurement assumptions temper confidence slightly.

Core claims are precise: welfare depends on average effects, variance, and targeting; average effects can be irrelevant with zero pass-through/optimal taxes. Evidence supports this via RCTs and structural sufficient statistics. Limits: artefactual designs, proxy-based bias in SSB, normality/measurement error assumptions.

Clear welfare derivations, use of Weyl-Fabinger pass-through, mixed-effects estimation of ATE, variance, covariances; pass-through and markup handled via literature. Robustness, alternative specs, and appendices are solid. Key assumptions (normality, bias measurement, linearity) are acknowledged but nontrivial.

Shifts evaluation of nudges from average effects to distortion variance/targeting within a portable public finance framework. Offers practical sufficient statistics and shows conditions where nudges can reduce welfare. Likely to influence behavioral public finance and policy appraisal.

Clear setup, motivating examples, formal propositions, and transparent mapping to empirics. Figures/tables elucidate tradeoffs. Caveats and limitations are explicitly discussed; reasoning is coherent and consistent with results.

Pre-registered trials; replication files reportedly available; extensive appendices. No full pre-analysis plan due to structural focus; some data sources proprietary/panel recruitment. Overall good transparency and reproducibility.

Direct relevance to labeling/nudge policies (fuel economy, SSB), taxation, and market power—topics of broad policy interest. Provides actionable guidance on when nudges help or hurt. Generalizability beyond experiments is limited but insights are widely applicable.

Multi-country RCTs across five LMICs; large, policy-relevant effects (0.30–0.35 SD pooled; up to 0.89). Strong external validity via diverse contexts and gov/NGO arms; careful assessment validity checks; compelling cost-effectiveness. Minor caveats: heterogeneity in SMS arm, some cluster-level randomization complexities.

Claims are clear and tied to preregistered-style RCT logic; multiple robustness checks, pooling and country analyses, and typhoon quasi-experiment. Well-bounded claims on scalability and gov delivery. Some limits: duration short; learning outcomes primarily numeracy; longer-term persistence not shown.

Appropriate randomization, blocking, clustering, multiple contexts; careful measurement QA for phone assessments; ITT focus; heterogeneity, balance, attrition checks. Some arms randomized at clusters with low ICC; limited multiplicity adjustments; cost methods summarized but not fully granular.

Addresses key gap in education-in-emergencies with rare multi-country RCTs and gov vs NGO implementation test. Demonstrates scalable, cost-effective tutoring via phones, and teacher practice/belief spillovers. Adds evidence on remote assessment validity and LAYS-based benchmarking.

Clear motivation, design, and interpretation; consistent linkage from evidence to conclusions; visuals and tables communicate well; limitations noted. Dense in places; some cost-effectiveness assumptions condensed; could streamline presentation of multiple outcomes.

NBER working paper with extensive methodological detail and appendices. However, it’s unclear if deidentified data, code, and instruments are fully public. Monitoring tools described but not evidently deposited. Moderate replicability; could improve with full data/code release.

High policy salience for LMICs facing frequent shocks; results span five countries, multiple languages, gov systems; strong cost-effectiveness and practicality for scale. Directly informs donors and ministries on resilient delivery during closures and beyond.

Ambitious, well-identified firm-level study linking agency budget shocks to three channels of public science. Strong datasets, careful IV strategy, extensive robustness and heterogeneity. Clear, policy-relevant findings. Minor limits: U.S.-centric, complex instruments require assumptions; some constructs depend on proprietary/assembled data.

Core claims are explicit and matched to evidence across patents, publications, scientists, R&D, and value. Multiple IVs, first-stage strength, alternative measures, and Poisson CF bolster credibility. Some residual concerns about exclusion restrictions and exposure share stability remain but are addressed.

Innovative shift-share IVs predicted by subcommittee composition; granular exposure using SPECTER and bibliometrics; firm and year FE; many robustness and heterogeneity checks. Assumptions (political instruments exogeneity, mapping accuracies) are discussed and partially validated.

Clarifies roles of publications, people, and university patents on corporate R&D with novel identification and data. Challenges standard spillover narratives; practical insights for science policy and corporate strategy. Strong contribution to innovation/IO and management of science.

Clear conceptual framework, transparent derivations, tables and appendices well-structured. Long and dense, but argument flows logically and links theory to empirics carefully. Minor complexity could hinder accessibility to non-specialists.

Uses external datasets (Dimensions, PatentsView, PQDT); mentions availability of DISCERN/Zenodo resource. However, full replication may be hard due to proprietary/licensed data, complex matching, and unclear code release. Good methodological detail but limited full reproducibility.

High relevance for R&D and science policy; insights on universities, startups, incumbents. Identification uses U.S. political process; results strongest for U.S. context and life sciences. Concepts generalize, but policy levers and magnitudes may vary internationally.

Large-N admin data, clear identification exploiting batch thresholds and weather-induced timing noise; strong first-stage and robustness. Substantive, policy-relevant results with careful heterogeneity and panel checks. Some residual concerns about instrument construction and assumptions, but overall highly convincing.

Main claims are specific and matched to evidence. Placebos, balance, time dynamics, and heterogeneity support interpretation. Potential alternative channels are discussed. Remaining risks: instrument validity relies on rain permutations and mapping to census numbers.

Innovative RVI/RD-IV framework, clear design, good first-stage strength, panel DiD corroboration, extensive FE and controls. Assumptions (local weather exogeneity, mapping model) are plausible but complex; limited formal sensitivity to alternative weather models.

New evidence on legalization’s impact on entrepreneurship in LMIC context and a methodological extension for RD with noisy running variables. Offers actionable insights for migration policy; complements literature on legalization impacts beyond labor markets.

Well-structured narrative, clearly explains policy, data, and identification. Figures and tables align with arguments. Some technical sections dense but generally transparent about assumptions and limitations.

Uses confidential administrative data and proprietary weather data; replication may be constrained. Methods are well-described, but no explicit mention of code/data release or preregistration. Some openness via detailed appendix.

Directly relevant to migration regularization policies in emerging economies; clear implications for entrepreneurship, formalization, and integration. Findings likely generalizable to similar contexts and useful for policymakers.

Ambitious factorial RCT with novel TVA method; strong empirical execution, clear winner’s-curse adjustment, and policy relevance. Large sample, careful design, convincing results. Minor caveats on external validity and some assumptions for selection consistency.

Core claims (TVA, identification of best bundles, cost-effectiveness) are well-defined and supported by pre-specified design, large-scale data, robustness checks, and winner’s-curse correction. Remaining risks: model-selection assumptions and finite-sample sensitivities.

Methodological contribution (TVA, Puffer-LASSO, post-selection OLS, asymptotics) is rigorous; simulations extensive; adjustment for multiple comparisons is principled. Assumptions (beta-min, homoskedasticity) and irrepresentability handling are discussed but still somewhat strong.

Advances design/analysis for complex policy bundles and shows complementarities in immunization nudges. Provides a practical path to select scalable policies. Value both for econometrics of experiments and applied health policy.

Clear problem framing, lattice intuition, algorithm steps, and link from theory to practice. Figures/tables aid understanding. Length and technical density may challenge some readers but reasoning is coherent.

Design and procedure are well-documented; simulations described; implementation details and appendices substantial. Full replication packages/data availability are not fully evident from text; admin data access may be restricted.
High policy relevance for immunization and for any multi-arm, multi-dose policy selection. Direct implications for LMIC health programs and beyond; quantified impacts and costs provided.

Innovative TVA method for high-dimensional policy selection plus a large, policy-relevant RCT on immunization. Strong design, careful post-selection inference (winner’s curse), extensive simulations, and clear applied results. Some dependence on assumptions; complexity may limit accessibility.

Main questions and claims are explicit (identify best and most cost-effective bundles). Evidence from a 915-village RCT, pre-specified logic, and robust adjustments. Minor concerns: finite-sample nuances and reliance on modeling choices for selection/penalties.

Methodological contribution (TVA) with LASSO preconditioning, support recovery, post-selection OLS, and hybrid CIs. Theory, proofs, and rich simulations. Assumptions (beta-min, homoskedasticity) and complexity are limitations but well-discussed.

Advances design/analysis for factorial policy bundles and shows complementarities in practice. Offers a template for applied work beyond this context. Impactful but dependent on settings where TVA assumptions are tenable.
Clear articulation of problem, TVA steps, assumptions, and policy interpretation. Figures/tables helpful; appendices thorough. Dense technical sections may challenge non-specialists.

ArXiv availability, extensive appendices, algorithms and simulation details. Full replication materials and data access less clear (sensitive admin data). Method description likely sufficient for reimplementation.

Childhood immunization uptake is a major global priority. Results give implementable guidance (incentives+information hubs+SMS; cost-effective variant). Lessons generalize to other multi-arm policy choices.

Large, well-executed village-level RCT on UBI with strong design, high compliance, high response rates, careful econ analysis, and meaningful, policy-relevant results. Clear contrasts across LT/ST/LS and theorized mechanisms. Minor limitations: early-wave results, some imprecision for prices/spillovers.

Claims closely match evidence: preregistered outcomes, extensive robustness, clear ITT focus, transparent power limits for cross-arm differences. Strong first-stage/compliance and balance. Some outcomes noisy (prices, some assets), but characterization cautious.

Stratified cluster randomization, village-level aggregation, Conley SEs, migrant tracking, multiple data sources. Thoughtful theory to interpret mechanisms. Limits: limited power for arm-vs-arm, early measurement point, some self-assessed asset values.

First large-scale experimental evidence on LT UBI vs short-term streams vs lump-sum with GE features. Novel insights on occupational shifts, enterprise expansion, and tranching. High impact for social protection design in LMICs.
Clear setup, motivation, framework, and presentation. Results tie back to hypotheses; limitations discussed. Dense in places but overall rigorous and coherent.
Pre-analysis plan and detailed appendices; methods transparent. Data/code availability not fully evident in text; some admin data proprietary. Good but not exemplary reproducibility.
Direct relevance to cash transfer policy, UBI design, and poverty programs in LMICs; findings on tranching and duration highly actionable for donors and governments.

Timely and rigorous simulation of vaccine megafund economics with clear policy implications. Solid calibration, extensive sensitivity analysis, and transparent limitations. Some assumptions (price, outbreak processes, correlation metric) are stylized, but conclusions are carefully qualified.

Core claims are explicit: diversified mRNA vaccine portfolios are unlikely to be privately profitable without public support; price per dose dominates. Evidence via Monte Carlo with sensitivity checks. Reliant on parameter assumptions and expert input; no empirical validation, but characterization is honest.

Appropriate stochastic portfolio model, correlated Bernoulli generation, cost structures, and outbreak modeling. Sensitivity spans key drivers. Correlation construction is heuristic; demand and competitive dynamics simplified; no code audit presented. Still strong for policy-simulation standards.

Clarifies why EID vaccine portfolios face poor private returns even with mRNA and diversification; quantifies subsidy/pricing thresholds and trial cost shares. Extends prior megafund work with richer revenue/outbreak modeling. Useful for funders and policymakers.

Clear narrative, explicit assumptions, modular framework, and consistent conclusions. Figures/tables support claims; limitations and policy levers are well discussed. Minor complexity in correlation metric could use more validation detail.

Model structure and parameters are documented with supplements, but no public code/data repository is evident. Reproducibility would benefit from shared simulation code and input files; otherwise reasonably described for conceptual replication.

High relevance to pandemic preparedness, vaccine financing, and public-private partnership design. Direct implications for pricing, AMCs, stockpiling, and portfolio strategy across EIDs. Broad applicability across income settings.

Large, well-executed RCT on CBT in rural Ghana; clear positive effects on mental/physical health, socioemotional skills, and short-run economic proxies. Careful RI inference and heterogeneity via LASSO. Limitations: short follow-up (2–3 months), reliance on self-reports, external validity and durability uncertain.

Claims are specific and matched to measured outcomes; heterogeneity framed carefully. Evidence strong for short-run indices with RI p-values. Less certain on long-run or hard economic outcomes. No overreach on durability, but some mechanistic claims (bandwidth) rest on proxy measures.

Multi-stage randomization with rerandomization for balance, RI, pre-specified indices, multiplicity awareness; LASSO with sample-splitting for heterogeneity. Potential concerns: self-report bias, partial reliance on index construction, short horizon; but overall methodological rigor is high.

Shifts CBT from targeted clinical groups to general poor populations; links therapy to human capital and bandwidth. Contrasts with nulls in Kenya study by intensity/timing. Valuable practical insight, but impact persistence unknown; economic outcomes are proximate, not income/productivity.

Clear theory of change (vulnerability + bandwidth), transparent design, thorough appendix and ethics. Results presented with RI and heterogeneity carefully explained. Minor risk of narrative over-interpretation on mechanisms, but generally well argued and consistent.

NBER WP with detailed methods, curriculum manual available and structured ethics appendix. Data/code availability not clearly provided at WP stage; replication materials uncertain. Manualization aids replication of intervention, but full open materials not evident.

High policy relevance for LMICs: scalable group CBT by lay counselors, mental health as SDG, potential to integrate with service schemes. Useful near-term effect sizes for practitioners. Main caveat is unknown long-term persistence and cost-effectiveness over time.

Strong multi-game experimental design, preregistered hypotheses, novel real-stakes trolley implementation, and clear, policy-relevant insights. Some limits: student-heavy sample, mostly online stakes, context-specificity complicates external validity. Nonetheless, rigor and clarity place it near top of recent behavioral/moral econ.

Core claims—prevalence of deontological choices, low cross-situation consistency, weak trolley predictiveness, orthogonality to prosociality—are well supported by within-subject design, aligned variants, attention checks, and robustness. Effect sizes and multiple comparisons are handled reasonably; remaining threats modest.

Well-justified tasks, preregistration, comprehension checks, aligned treatments, and robustness analyses. Innovative SAL paradigm. Constraints: student/online sample, moderate stakes/10% implementation in SAL, some binary outcomes, limited structural modeling, and generalizability across cultures/contexts.

Introduces flexible ends-versus-means paradigm, real-stakes trolley, and documents key null of trait-like stability. Clarifies limits of trolley as predictor and separability from SVO. Likely to shape future experimental and theoretical work on moral decision-making.

Clear research questions, consistent logic from design to inference, transparent reporting, figures and matrices aid interpretation. Caveats and robustness well laid out. Minor density in appendices but overall excellent exposition.

Preregistration and ethics approvals stated; clear procedures and attention checks. Data/code availability not explicit in provided text; if later shared, score would rise. Overall good transparency but uncertain replication package.

Findings matter for AI, public policy, and applied ethics by showing context-dependence in ends-versus-means choices and limits of trolley generalization. Immediate policy prescriptions limited; population and context may constrain direct transfer.

Strong, rigorous framework for correcting SWB scale-use heterogeneity; multiple estimators, simulations, and applications. Clear impact on key SWB results (means, regressions, variances). Well-argued assumptions and diagnostics. Limitations: MTurk sample, reliance on CQs and linearity/consistency assumptions.

Claims are precise (general vs dimensional scale use, shifter/stretcher model). Evidence includes theory, CQ and SWB data, MLE and semi-parametric estimators, simulations, and validations (objective vs subjective). Some assumptions remain untestable; vignette biases acknowledged.

Methodologically sophisticated: clear identification via CQs, linear translation framework, MOM/semi-parametric/MLE estimators, bias formulas, bootstrap SEs, robustness simulations, persistence analysis. Careful treatment of error structure. Assumption burden noted.

Provides practical, generalizable toolkit for SWB research; clarifies when adjustments matter; large variance corrections; guidance for practitioners and future surveys. Bridges literatures on response styles and SWB. Implications for experiments and inequality measures.

Well-structured exposition from motivation to theory, estimation, applications, and caveats. Clear definitions (height, MMB), transparent derivations, and limitations. Dense in places; some technical sections require effort but remain coherent.

Preregistration and extensive web appendices. Model and estimation details are replicable. It’s unclear if full code/data are publicly released; MTurk data may have sharing limits. Overall above-average transparency, not exemplary without full artifacts.

SWB measurement is globally relevant for policy and welfare analysis. Methods generalize beyond US MTurk. Applications demonstrate material changes to common findings. External validity of empirical sample is limited; uptake depends on adding CQs to major surveys.

Large-N, 20-year staggered rollout with TWFE and modern estimators; integrates satellites, DHS, and ACLED; clear, policy-relevant results with distributional nuance. Some limitations: observational design, potential unobserved shocks, partial data sharing on interventions.

Claims are specific (ag production, child nutrition, conflict gradients) and backed by event studies, fixed effects, and robust patterns. Pre-trend checks shown. Some secondary outcomes (ecology) rely on visual interpretation; causality on distal spillovers less tight.

Appropriate TWFE with heterogeneity-aware estimators; geospatial linkage; multiple data sources; distance bands. Remaining concerns: selection into sites, residual confounding, modest power for DHS subgroups, and limited mechanistic checks for distal spillovers and ecology.

Rare long-run evidence on small-scale irrigation in conflict settings, linking production, nutrition, and conflict with spatial spillovers. Provides durable-impact insights and highlights tradeoffs for practitioners. Fills a notable gap in Africa Sahel resilience literature.

Clear narrative, figures, and event-study plots; transparent about limits and distributional effects. Some technical details deferred to supplements; a fuller discussion of alternative mechanisms and falsification tests could strengthen.

Uses publicly accessible NDVI/NDWI, DHS, ACLED; methods described. Intervention geodata available on request rather than fully open; commercial VHR imagery not shareable; code/data packaging not fully standardized.

High policy salience for climate adaptation, food security, and conflict in Sahelian contexts; directly informs donors/governments on small-scale irrigation benefits and tradeoffs. Generalizable to similar semi-arid riverine systems.

Ambitious theory-data synthesis linking zero-sum environments to demotivating beliefs with clear predictions tested in DRC and WVS. Strong coherence, extensive robustness, and interesting welfare vs well-being divergence. Limits: largely observational (associational), PCA-based constructs, and external validity/causality caveats.

Core claims are precise and mapped to testable predictions. Multiple samples, validation checks, and robustness support them. However, identification is correlational; mechanisms are inferred rather than causally pinned down, and some constructs rely on survey measures.

Evolutionary model is well-specified; empirical work uses careful index construction, fixed effects, validations, and robustness. Still, reliance on OLS with limited causal strategies; potential residual confounding and measurement error in perceived zero-sumness.

Introduces and empirically tests an evolutionary account of effort-suppressing beliefs; bridges anthropology, econ theory, and cross-country data. Offers new testable divergence between material welfare and well-being with policy-relevant insights.
Very clear framing, definitions, and mapping from theory to empirics. Predictions summarized and matched to evidence; figures/tables effective; limitations acknowledged. Strong narrative coherence.

WVS is public; DRC data/instruments and code availability not fully clear from text. Methods are transparent, but full replication packages and preregistration/multiplicity controls are not emphasized.

High relevance for development, cultural economics, and policy discourse on competition and social beliefs. Results span low- and high-income contexts; offers guidance for interpreting zero-sum perceptions and outcomes, though policy prescriptions are indirect.

Clear, practically useful guidance on internal/external validity adjustments for CEAs. Synthesizes meta-research well and offers actionable heuristics and a worked example. Limited novelty and empirical validation; relies on expert judgment and secondary evidence. Strong for practitioner use within EA/global dev contexts.

Main claims are explicit (Type M/S, external validity) and supported by credible literature. Quantitative recommendations are reasoned but partly heuristic; some estimates extrapolate from fields with differing contexts. Would benefit from more systematic benchmarking and sensitivity analyses.

Methodological framing is solid (Gelman & Carlin, Vivalt, Duflo/Banerjee). Provides power-based rules, retrodesign use, bias checks. However, no new empirical tests; limited formal validation across case studies; some steps depend on subjective priors and rough adjustments.

Adds a structured, practitioner-oriented approach to discounting RCTs for CEAs and emphasizes power-driven inflation. Advances practice more than theory; useful for funders/evaluators. Incremental contribution relative to existing meta-research.

Well organized, clear separation of internal vs external validity and Type M vs Type S. Concrete guidance and example. Figures and tables aid intuition. Some repetition and reliance on external links; a concise checklist or decision tree could improve.

Cites sources extensively and suggests tools (retrodesign). Limited sharing of code/data, preregistration, or replication packages. A public library of discounts is mentioned but not fully integrated. Transparency good; reproducibility limited.

Highly relevant to global health/development CEAs and policy translation of RCTs. Emphasis on generalizability and scale-up effects is valuable. Less directly applicable outside impact evaluation domains or where RCTs are sparse.

High-quality long-run follow-up of psychotherapy RCTs in India. Strong, policy-relevant findings on persistent mental-health impacts, careful behavioral measurements, and expert-forecast component. Transparent analyses and multiplicity control. Some limits: attrition, external validity, and null economic outcomes.

Main claims are clear and well-bounded: persistent depression reduction (HAP), no long-run economic gains, changes in beliefs/preferences. Evidence from preregistered RCT follow-up, validated PHQ-9, multiple robustness checks. Appropriate nuance on THPP nulls. Remaining concerns: self-report outcomes, attrition, limited power for some nulls.

Solid RCT design, pre-analysis plan, DML controls, FDR corrections, belief-updating structural estimation, robustness filters. Attrition balanced; machine-learning HTE explored. Limits: 76% follow-up, reliance on PHQ-9 screening tool, some exploratory mediation; external validity to other contexts uncertain.

Advances evidence on long-run psychotherapy effects in LMICs; quantifies months of depression averted and cost-effectiveness; novel behavioral-beliefs mechanisms; expert forecast comparison. Influential for global mental health and development economics.

Clear exposition, pre-specified primary families, careful interpretation of nulls, figures/tables informative, limitations discussed. Technical appendices thorough. Minor complexity in belief tasks may tax readers but presentation remains careful.

Preregistration and detailed methods; extensive appendices. Data/code availability not clearly provided with the WP; replication package status unclear. Some proprietary elements (field data) may limit full reproducibility.

Strong relevance to LMIC mental health policy and program design; cost-effectiveness estimates actionable. Null economic outcomes inform realistic expectations and integration with other interventions. Applicability highest to similar contexts (female-heavy samples).

Compelling, well-argued thesis linking citation incentives to stagnation, with clear conceptual model and suggestive empirics. Strong synthesis across literatures. Limited causal identification and reliance on illustrative cases temper overall strength.

Main claims are clear; evidence is a mix of literature synthesis, case studies (PCR/CRISPR), and prior text-mining work. Empirical demonstration of novelty vs impact is descriptive. Causality largely argued, not shown.

Simple conceptual model; descriptive analytics for novelty metric. Lacks preregistration, robustness, and formal causal strategies in this paper. Methods reasonable for a perspective piece but not rigorous empirics.
Frames an influential narrative on incentives and proposes actionable novelty metrics. Advances discussion in science policy and measurement. Contribution is more agenda-setting than definitive.

Clear structure, persuasive logic, helpful figures, well-motivated anecdotes, and transparent assumptions. Conclusions follow from premises; communication accessible to broad policy and academic audiences.
Working paper accessible; methods described, but no new shared datasets or code here. Prior related work uses public vocabularies; reproducibility details are limited in this paper.

High relevance for research policy, funding, and evaluation across fields and countries. Practical suggestions for funders, universities, and platforms. Less directly tied to specific global health or climate outcomes.

Ambitious, carefully executed paper combining time-series identification with panel validation and structural mapping to welfare/SCC. Extensive robustness, strong empirical patterns, and large policy relevance. Remaining uncertainty on external validity and bold magnitudes prevents a perfect score.

Core claims are explicit (global vs local temp impacts; SCC magnitude). Evidence includes multiple robustness checks, alternative samples, controls, and mechanisms via extremes. Some residual identification debate and linearity/extrapolation risks remain.

Well-justified local projections, shock construction, controls, cross-validation in panel, alternative filters, VAR check, and sequence-space structural mapping. Reverse causality correction reasoned and small. Concerns: reliance on linearity, persistence assumptions, and aggregate data limits.

Substantial shift in estimated macro damages and SCC; reconciles discrepancy with prior local-temperature literature; links extremes mechanism; provides structural damages and policy implications. Likely to reshape research and policy debates.

Clear question, transparent assumptions, thorough appendices, figures, and sensitivity analyses. Logical flow from reduced-form to structural results. Complexity is high but explanations are careful and consistent.

Uses public, regularly updated datasets and provides detailed methodological appendix. Replicability appears high; exact code/data availability is not specified here, so score reflects uncertainty rather than shortcomings.

Direct implications for global welfare, SCC, and unilateral policy incentives. Strong salience for macro, climate policy, and international coordination. Broad applicability across regions and income levels.

Well-executed RCT on informal firms’ taxation with clear findings: reduced extensive-margin participation but higher activity and revenues. Sound design, balance checks, ANCOVA, IV for knowledge uptake, theory to rationalize results. Limits: modest N, single-city context, missing tax-amount data, self-reports, mechanisms not definitively pinned, no prereg noted.

Main claims are explicit and tested. ITT effects on participation robust across specs; knowledge manipulation validated; heterogeneous patterns align with model. Evidence on tax revenue relies on many imputed zeros and missing receipts—interpret cautiously. Qualitative follow-up supports mechanisms but is not definitive.

Randomization, balance, ANCOVA, IV-LATE for knowledge uptake, and heterogeneity are appropriate. Power is moderate; outcome measurement for revenue is noisy; missing data on tax payments; no explicit multiplicity control or prereg; potential spillovers not rigorously ruled out. Still, identification for main ITT is credible.

Novel focus on civic information as empowerment in informal sector taxation; counterintuitive and policy-relevant results that nuance assumptions about tax education. Extends literature beyond deterrence nudges; practical insights for LMIC revenue authorities on sorting and participation margins.

Clear motivation, context, intervention description, and theory consistent with results. Figures/tables helpful; reasoning transparent. Some sections lengthy; ancillary tests relegated to appendix could be better integrated; clarity around imputation choices could be tighter.

Methods and outcomes are described in good detail, but no explicit preregistration, analysis plan, code, or data availability noted. Replication facilitated by clear descriptions yet hindered by lack of shared materials at this stage.

High salience for tax capacity, informality, and MSME policy in LMICs. Actionable implications for taxpayer education design and auditing focus. External validity beyond Lomé plausible for similar settings, but institutional specifics limit broad generalization.

Interesting and policy-relevant topic with a creative elicitation design. However, strong hypothetical bias, extreme skew, small sample, and sensitive exclusion rules limit credibility of quantitative claims. Reasoned discussion and transparency about limitations improve value, but applied utility hinges on future replication with stronger designs.

Main qualitative claims (many think farm animals’ lives not worth living; chicken vs beef welfare costs) broadly supported. Quantitative magnitudes (very high mean WTA/kg) are fragile, sensitive to outliers and decisions, and acknowledged as such. Evidence sufficient for directional insights, not precise estimates.

Contingent valuation with pill scenario is inventive but highly hypothetical; WTA/WTP gaps, extreme outliers, modest N, limited power, and heavy reliance on exclusions/winsorization weaken inference. No preregistration; limited robustness checks; no behavioral incentive compatibility. Nonparametric tests appropriate but underpowered.

Pushes animal welfare economics toward explicit external cost quantification and explores policy interactions (carbon vs welfare). Novel representative-agent framing and relative WTP concept are useful. Despite limitations, advances discussion and offers hypotheses for future rigorous work.

Clear setup, definitions, and careful caveats about bias and sensitivity. Logical derivations of welfare measures and policy implications generally consistent with results. Some sections long and occasionally speculative, but argumentation is transparent overall.

No clear indication of shared data, questionnaire instrument, code, or preregistration. Methods description is detailed enough to roughly replicate survey, but full reproducibility seems limited without materials and data availability.

High-stakes domain (animal welfare, meat policy, climate). Belgian sample limits external validity; results are primarily directional. Practical takeaways (risk of beef-to-chicken shift; flat tax concept) are globally relevant but require better-calibrated estimates.

Nationwide RCT leveraging administrative CEMS data; strong causal identification, mechanism and GE tests, substantial effects, and policy relevance. Minor limitations: external validity beyond China’s context and medium-run horizon.

Clear questions; ITT estimates with firm and province-day FE, clustered SEs; event studies and robustness checks; manipulation checks; mechanism experiments (visibility); GE via cross-randomization. Strong internal validity.

Well-justified design; prereg RCT ID; careful verification of violations; appropriate fixed effects and clustering; heterogeneity; falsification checks; IV corroboration. Remaining risks: medium duration, potential unobserved channels.

First large-scale experimental evidence on citizen participation via social media affecting enforcement and emissions, with GE. Bridges governance, environment, and social media literatures; practical insights for policy.
Clear motivation, design diagrams, transparent assumptions, consistent conclusions; thorough appendices. Dense at times but logically structured.
RCT registry and data appendix. Uses administrative data not fully public; replication may require restricted access. Materials and scripts partially described.
High relevance for pollution control, regulatory accountability, and gov-citizen interaction in LMICs; scalable and cost-effective pathways; quantified impacts on emissions and ambient SO2.

Well-executed discrete choice experiments with strong design, compelling heterogeneity, and policy relevance. External validity limited by simulated setting and response bias; lacks direct outcome linkage to realized scientific impact. Clear writing and solid robustness raise confidence.

Main claims are precise and supported by randomized score distributions, fixed-effects CL/GMNL models, and sensitivity checks. However, claims about funding reversals rely on simulations and repurposed datasets; causal link to downstream impact is inferred, not shown.

Appropriate DCE/BIBD, conditional logit with clustered SEs, multinomial/GMNL robustness, and heterogeneity via MeSH overlap. Concerns: 9% response, potential selection, self-reported hovering, external validity of hypothetical choices, bounded-scale artifacts.

Advances understanding of how reviewers value dissensus and variance, informing funding-rule reforms. Bridges evidence to actionable rules (tie-breaking with variance). Novel expert-vs-outsider dissensus result. Impact tempered by lack of agency field trials.

Clear motivation, NIH process description, experimental protocols, and econometric exposition. Results logically connected to claims; limitations acknowledged. Figures/tables are interpretable; appendices deepen transparency.

Data appendix available and methods well-described. Full anonymized datasets/code availability not fully evident; reliance on third-party datasets with constraints. Replication feasible but may require access permissions.

High relevance to major funders (NIH, NSF, global agencies) and philanthropic R&D. Offers implementable tweaks (variance weighting or tie-breaking). Direct practitioner utility; applicability beyond biomedicine with caveats.

Ambitious multi-study program with large samples, pre-registration, clear constructs, and transparent analyses. Integrates moral psychology and population ethics with novel findings. Some reliance on MTurk/Prolific, hypothetical scenarios, and complex numeracy limits generality.

Claims closely track presented evidence across nine experiments. Multiple converging manipulations and checks. Some interpretations (e.g., cognitive mechanisms) are suggestive rather than decisive; generalization beyond online US samples is limited.

Pre-registered studies, attention/manipulation checks, large N, randomized designs, and robustness tests. Limitations: hypothetical judgments, measurement complexity (averages/totals), potential framing/scale assumptions, and exclusion rates.

Pioneers systematic empirical work on population-ethical intuitions, informing debates on totalism/averagism/asymmetry. Provides actionable stylized facts and thinking-style effects; establishes a foundation for future work.
Well-structured argument, clear research questions and links to theory, careful caveats, and comprehensive discussion. Figures/tables effectively communicate results; limitations candidly addressed.
Strong OSF sharing of data, code, and materials; multiple pre-registrations; ethics approvals reported; full reporting of manipulations/measures/exclusions.

High relevance for moral philosophy, longtermism discourse, and value aggregation debates; indirect for immediate policy. Useful to practitioners in global priorities research; less direct for mainstream policy implementation.

Clear question contrasting epidemiological accounting with reduced-form economics on measles. Strong data assembly and validation; careful comparisons; policy-relevant takeaways. Limits: age-unobserved cases, reliance on state-level proxies, and some counterintuitive epi-model results after cohort FEs. Still a valuable, credible contribution.

Claims are scoped to US measles cohorts and to comparing approaches. Evidence includes predictive checks for SIR-based susceptibles and multiple outcome domains with robustness to cohort FEs for reduced-form. Epi model’s null/negative results are frankly reported. Some identification hinges on mortality as severity proxy.

Epi accounting model built on SIR with reporting-rate estimation; sensitivity analyses (reporting, susceptibility, age risk). Reduced-form aligns with established designs, with FE/trend specs and clustered SEs. Constraints: no state-level rollout rates, potential measurement error in DOB, ecological aggregation.

Clarifies when epidemiological accounting adds value vs. reduced-form severity proxies for long-run human capital. Helps reconcile literatures and guides future vaccine-impact work. Novel comparative framing; generalizability beyond measles is argued but bounded.

Well-structured, transparent assumptions, figures compare measures clearly, acknowledges caveats. Logical linkage from model validation to long-run outcomes. Minor density in appendices but overall very clear.

Uses public datasets (Tycho, Vital Statistics, Census/ACS) and details construction. However, no explicit code/data repository is provided; some inputs (state-level vaccination rates) not available and approximated nationally.

Findings inform vaccine policy prioritization where child disease burden is high and underscore benefits even in high-income contexts. Relevance to global vaccination strategy and cost-benefit analysis; direct estimates are US-specific.

Rigorous, well-argued applied analysis integrating growth, health, and existential risk with extensive sensitivity checks. Clear framing, credible use of XPT forecasts, and thoughtful parameterization. Some reliance on contest forecasts and value assumptions limits certainty; model scope excludes some pathways.

Main claims are explicit; evidence combines historical trends, frontier estimates, and structured use of forecasting data. Characterization of uncertainty is careful. Dependence on elicited forecasts and strong utility assumptions reduces evidential strength versus empirical causal designs.

Transparent models, alternative specifications (closed-form and simulated), and robustness checks on key parameters (d, T, p, health modeling). Assumptions are sometimes stylized; limited empirical identification; some conversions (e.g., ROI scaling) hinge on debatable shares and lags.

Offers a novel, decision-relevant quantitative framework for metascience policy under bio risk; clarifies break-evens and tradeoffs practitioners face. Bridges econ growth, health, and risk in a usable way for philanthropy and policy audiences.

Exceptionally clear structure, definitions, and decomposition. Logical consistency with explicit caveats. Extensive technical appendices support transparency. Minor complexity may challenge non-technical readers.

Report and appendices are detailed with formulas and parameter sources. Uses public datasets/estimates. Code availability is unclear; some steps would benefit from shared notebooks/data for replication.

High-stakes topic with global implications for science, health, and catastrophic risk. Policy-relevant insights and quantified thresholds. Tailored partly to philanthropic decision-making may limit direct governmental uptake.

Policy-relevant, carefully executed meta-analysis expanding beyond IQ to learning. Adjusts for publication bias and confounding, provides simulations and practical implications. Limits: reliance on observational studies, re-expression assumptions, sparse LMIC causal evidence. Strong contribution for global education and health policy.

Claims are clear and appropriately qualified. Evidence synthesized from 47 studies with PET-PEESE, sensitivity, and specification curves. However, causal claims remain bounded; IV evidence limited and heterogeneity high. Solid characterization of uncertainty.

Systematic search, robust variance meta-regression, publication-bias adjustments, Oster bounds, and harmonization steps. Re-expression of linear to log introduces potential bias; dependence on observational designs and imputed stats in places. Nonetheless, methods are transparent and competent.

Integrates IQ with reading/math, quantifies global learning gaps attributable to lead, and maps interventions to expected gains. Provides actionable benchmarks for practitioners and donors. Moves debate toward education impacts of environmental health.

Clear narrative, well-structured, figures and appendices aid transparency. Assumptions and limitations are stated. Policy simulations trace logic from effect sizes to national outcomes. Minor complexity in re-expression methods may challenge some readers.

Detailed appendices and procedures; cites algorithms and provides study lists. Data/code availability not fully evident for replication of all steps; some imputations not fully reproducible without shared code/data.

Directly targets LMIC learning shortfalls; quantifies potential gains from feasible interventions; highly relevant to ministries, donors, and NGOs across health and education. Strong alignment with global priorities.

Timely, decision-relevant comparison of resilient foods vs AGI safety using Monte Carlo with sensitivity analyses. Credible framing, acknowledges theory/model uncertainty. However, heavy reliance on subjective priors, small biased survey, and speculative far-future valuations limit confidence. Useful for practitioners despite epistemic caveats.

Core claims are explicit; evidence mixes literature, expert elicitations, and prior models. Sensitivity checks help, but survey n is small with potential demand/selection bias; independence assumptions and longtermist value metrics stretch evidential base. Conclusions are cautiously stated but still outrun support in places.

Appropriate probabilistic modeling and importance analysis; clear parameterization. Yet many inputs are subjective; AGI submodel inherits dated assumptions; cross-model comparability imperfect; dependence structures omitted. Robustness explored, but multiplicity and prior justification could be stronger.

Provides one of the first quantitative long-term cost-effectiveness comparisons of resilient foods vs AGI safety, highlighting underexplored resilience interventions and near-term urgency. Sparks methodological debate and practical prioritization despite uncertainties.

Logical structure and transparent reasoning; limitations and uncertainties discussed at length. Some sections dense; occasional overreach from speculative inputs to strong comparative statements. Figures and tables aid understanding.

Model implemented in Guesstimate and Analytica with parameters described; links imply some accessibility. However, full replication materials and data (survey microdata, code) are only partly available/‘upon request’. Better versioning and preregistration would help.

Directly targets high-stakes global catastrophes with actionable insights for funding allocation and preparedness; emphasizes low-cost, scalable interventions and policy timing. High salience for disaster risk reduction, food security, and longtermist stakeholders.

Thoughtful, decision-relevant forecasting with clear uncertainty, links to TEAs, and explicit cruxes. Transparent about limitations, conditioning, and aggregation. Useful for EA-aligned strategy. Not a full empirical study; small expert panel and limited horizon reduce confidence.

Main claims are clearly framed as probabilistic forecasts with context and signposts. Evidence synthesizes TEAs and expert panel inputs; acknowledges errors and biases. Lacks preregistered protocol and comprehensive sensitivity checks; limited external validation.

Reasonable question design and odds-based aggregation. Clear about conditioning (no TAI). Small N forecaster panel, short time budget, some wording errors, limited robustness tests. Correlation analysis basic; reference-class discussion qualitative. Still adequate for exploratory forecasting.

Clarifies realistic production timelines vs hype, informs funding priorities and research targets. Highlights key cruxes and levers (bioreactors, media, funding). Advances applied discourse in animal welfare and alt proteins; less novel for forecasting methodology.

Goals, assumptions, and limitations are explicit; figures and tables aid interpretation. Reasoning transparent, contrasts with consultancy projections, and articulates update triggers. Minor inconsistencies and lengthy narrative reduce crispness.

Shares anonymized forecasts, question list, and some code/data references; cites inputs extensively. Not a full preregistered protocol; some materials proprietary or external links. Replication feasible in spirit but not fully turnkey.

High practical relevance to animal welfare, philanthropy, and policy prioritization. Offers quantitative timelines and signposts useful for decision-makers. Less applicable outside alt proteins/EA contexts.

Clever design linking WTP for info to treatment via IPW; lab-field coherence; short- vs long-run dynamics; clear, policy-relevant insights. Some limits: student sample, pandemic-truncated N, field context narrow, effect decay. Still a strong, credible applied behavioral contribution.

Claims are specific and supported by preregistered analyses, lab RCT + field purchases, and robustness checks. Heterogeneity and decay well documented. Some uncertainty from classification of meals and external validity beyond canteens/students.

Incentivized MPL, induced variation, IPW identification, placebo and alternative specs; transparent handling of WTP bounds. Limits: reduced sample vs plan, potential measurement ambiguity for meals, student setting, and finite horizon for dynamics.

Bridges lab willful-ignorance literature to field behavior; quantifies selection on responsiveness and decay; informs targeting/cost-effectiveness of info campaigns. Provides actionable lessons for NGOs/policy.
Clear structure, theory-to-empirics link, figures/tables informative, limitations discussed. Dense appendices; some complexity in weighting/propensity exposition may challenge non-specialists.
Preregistration, IRB, detailed appendices, methods transparency. Data/code availability likely constrained (administrative canteen data, NGO video edits); replication materials not clearly public.

Relevant to animal welfare, climate-related consumption, and design of information interventions broadly. External generalizability beyond German students/canteens uncertain; short-lived effects temper practical impact.

Strong randomized governance intervention with clear outcomes, careful DID/event-study, robustness, and useful auxiliary analyses. Practical relevance high. Limits: bundled treatment can’t be unbundled; external validity beyond DRC uncertain; some data limitations; no preregistration noted.

Main claims are precise (efficiency, mortality). Evidence from randomized assignment and DID with event-time plots, bootstrapped SEs, and robustness checks is compelling. Interview evidence is supportive but limited. Measurement and reporting constraints in LMIC context remain.

Design leverages randomization within PDSS, DID with fixed effects, event-study pre-trend checks, multiple outcomes, bootstrapping, and matched comparisons to outside group. Threats discussed. Limits: bundled components, potential data quality issues, no preregistration/multiplicity plan beyond q-values.

Advances literature on performance-based financing by showing effectiveness when bundled with auditing/feedback; informs governance of nonprofits in LMICs. Contribution is applied but meaningful; generalizability and mechanism decomposition remain open.
Clear motivation, theory of complementarities, transparent identification, coherent results, and policy discussion. Figures/tables aid understanding. Well-structured and cautious about limits.

Administrative data described and identifiers noted; data appendix exists. However, underlying data likely restricted; code availability unclear; no preregistration. Replication feasible with access but not turnkey.
Directly relevant to global health delivery and donor policy in LMICs; quantifies effects on mortality and efficiency; actionable for practitioners. Context-specificity slightly tempers universality.

Strong, policy-relevant framing linking pharma pricing to global public goods; combines theory with transparent back-of-envelope empirics. Evidence is credible but rests on simplifying assumptions (MC proxies, quasi-rents as contributions), limited causal identification, and modest robustness. Communication is clear; usefulness for policy discussions is high.

Main claims are explicit: US bears disproportionate quasi-rent burden; ROW partially free rides; contributions scale with GDP. Evidence triangulates RAND prices and simple regressions. However, MC assumptions, basket comparability, endogeneity, and measurement error constrain strength; sensitivity is limited though two MC values are tried.

Theory is standard (Samuelson/Lindahl; Nash; alliances). Empirics use transparent construction of contributions and OLS on GDP with dummies. Reasonable, but identification is descriptive; potential confounding and simultaneity not addressed; robustness limited beyond alternative MC and functional form. Still appropriate for the question’s scope.

Clarifies partial free-riding narrative with quantified contributions; links to alliance theory and offers policy levers. Adds synthesized, updated cross-country estimates leveraging RAND. Not a methodological breakthrough but provides actionable perspective for pricing and international coordination debates.

Clear statement of objectives, logical flow from theory to measurement to regression. Transparent formulas and worked examples; limitations acknowledged. Lengthy but organized; figures/tables aid comprehension. Some repetition and potential overreach in normative conclusions, but generally careful.

Data sources are public (RAND, PWT), and construction is described. However, no posted code/data package evident; some computations rely on transformed indices and assumptions that would benefit from replication files. Reproducibility is feasible but requires effort.

Directly relevant to international drug pricing, innovation incentives, and global health. Results inform US-ROW policy bargaining and cost-sharing debates. Applicability spans OECD; less direct for low-income settings but conceptually pertinent.

Clear question, rigorous inclusion of RCTs, robust analyses (RVE, publication-bias sensitivity), and careful interpretation. Findings are policy-relevant and temper prior optimism. Limitations: many self-reported outcomes, limited choice-architecture RCTs, heterogeneity, and some imputation choices. Strong but not definitive.

Claims are precise (small pooled SMD; RPM vs MAP distinction) and aligned with evidence. Publication-bias analyses strengthen credibility. Appropriate caution on substitution and external validity. Some reliance on coarse outcomes tempers strength.

Transparent RCT-only criteria, longest follow-up per intervention, RVE with small-sample correction, multiple publication-bias methods, prereg-like clarity. Reproducible pipeline. Constraints: limited eligible studies in key categories; some self-report; unspecified-null handling could bias slightly.

Reframes field by showing modest behavioral effects versus prior attitude-focused reviews; distinguishes MAP vs RPM outcomes; highlights research gaps. Practical implications for funders and practitioners. Advances are incremental given evidence limits.

Reasoning is coherent; moderators and limitations are explicitly discussed; figures/tables informative. Narrative is balanced and avoids overclaiming. Could further streamline dense sections and clarify some coding decisions.

Code/data repository DOI, Rmarkdown, containers, detailed extraction and conversions, author contacts, and robustness checks. Strong replicability culture; minor gaps possible in full datasets from all included studies.

High salience for climate, public health, and animal welfare. Actionable takeaways for institutions considering nudges/persuasion. Limits: generalizability across cultures and settings; many university contexts.

Ambitious synthesis applying MVPF to 96 climate policies with harmonized externality valuation and novel LBD sufficient-statistics. Strong empirical grounding, careful sensitivity, clear implications for policy portfolios. Minor uncertainties on incidence assumptions and LBD causality prevent 100.

Claims are explicit; evidence spans quasi-experimental literature, transparent translations to MVPF, and extensive robustness (SCC ranges, rebound, firm profits, LBD on/off). Some inputs (e.g., LBD causality, SCC incidence) rest on assumptions acknowledged but still uncertain.

Methodological contribution is strong: formal MVPF with LBD, decomposition, GE rebound, fiscal externalities. Harmonization across studies is careful. Limits: heterogeneity in original elasticities, some modeling choices (e.g., demand isoelasticity, AVERT marginal emissions) could bias estimates.

Reframes climate policy comparison beyond cost-per-ton, yielding actionable rankings (wind/PTC, residential solar, nudges on dirty grids, fuel taxes). Provides toolkit and unifies multiple literatures; likely to shape research and policy evaluation standards.

Clear structure, transparent equations, step-by-step MVPF builds, comprehensive figures/tables, candid caveats. Long and dense, but argument flow is consistent and careful about distributional weights and budget closure.

Code/data availability indicated; harmonized inputs and appendices detail mappings and assumptions. Some reliance on third-party models (AVERT, SCC) and proprietary datasets from literature; reproducibility is high but not perfect.

Directly targets climate policy prioritization with US and international applications; results highly policy-relevant globally (tax design, subsidies, PES). Explicit incidence to US vs global beneficiaries improves transferability.

Large preregistered multi-arm RCT with strong design, clear results, and policy-relevant comparisons. Robust analyses include ANCOVA, spillovers, heterogeneity, timing, demand-effect checks, and cost-effectiveness. Communication is clear. Minor limitations: no very short-run endline, possible limited data sharing.

Core claims are precise and supported by appropriately powered estimates, multiple outcomes with FDR control, and robustness checks. Bayesian reasoning strengthens interpretation of nulls. Transparent discussion of IPV signal and limitations.

Two-stage randomization, large N, stratification, ANCOVA, clustered SEs, spillover design, ITT, multiplicity control, demand-effect test, timing analysis. Minor concerns: no very-early follow-up; PM+ fidelity measurement mostly supervisory; some self-report outcomes.

Important comparative evidence cash vs psychotherapy in LMICs with null on PM+ and positive on cash; informs program design and cost-effectiveness. Adds nuance on complementarity and frequency of transfers. Generality to other contexts cautiously discussed.
Clear narrative, pre-analysis alignment, thorough appendices, figures/tables convey estimates and uncertainty. Limitations and alternative explanations addressed. Dense but coherent.

Pre-registered with detailed PAP; extensive online appendix. Data/code availability not fully evident for replication (privacy constraints likely). Good transparency, room to improve by releasing de-identified data/code.
High policy salience for poverty, mental health, and cash transfers in LMICs; cost comparisons practical. External validity beyond rural Kenya moderate but discussed.

Ambitious, well-executed meta-research with clear framework, massive multi-domain datasets, strong robustness, and compelling quasi-experiments. Results are novel, policy-relevant, and carefully contextualized. Minor concerns: residual selection/measurement limits and reliance on proprietary data for full replication.

Core claims are precise and consistently supported across papers and patents, with field/time normalization, FE models, and diff-in-diff on retractions. Multiple outcome measures corroborate. Causal language mostly cautious, though some mechanisms remain suggestive.

Sound construction of pivot via cosine similarity, extensive robustness (alternative codings, windows, panels), event-study DiD, IV via shocks. Remaining risks: author disambiguation limits, Dimensions field coding noise, unobserved confounding in observational segments.

Introduces a generalizable pivot metric and documents a pervasive, growing penalty with actionable implications for researchers, teams, funders, and org strategy. Bridges science and invention evidence and challenges popular exploration/outsider narratives.
Clear framing, definitions, and visualizations; consistent normalization; careful discussion of mechanisms and limitations; comprehensive SI. Arguments track evidence well without overreach.

Uses large third-party datasets (Dimensions, PatentsView, SciSciNet). Methods are transparent and many checks provided. Full replication may be constrained by proprietary data and unclear code/data release at time of draft.

High relevance for science policy, funding portfolios, crisis responsiveness, and R&D strategy. Broad applicability across fields and to technology. Less directly tied to specific global priority interventions than domain-specific causal studies.

High-quality RCT on salient policy problem; clear results with satellite validation; strong cost-effectiveness analysis. Credible design, large sample, careful monitoring. Minor limitations: reliance on remote-sensing thresholds, limited heterogeneity identification, scaling/monitoring challenges.

Main claims precise: upfront PES increases compliance and reduces burning; standard PES inframarginal. Evidence from RCT plus remote sensing aligns and is transparently contrasted across thresholds. Some uncertainty remains on mechanisms and external validity.

Village-level randomization, prespecified pooling, clustered SEs, Lee bounds for attrition, RF-based burn detection with holdout validation. Sensitivity to classification addressed. Limits: negative labels only in treatment for RS training; limited power for some heterogeneity; monitoring relies on farmer-initiated calls.

Novel contract-design result for PES/CTs in LMIC agriculture with major environmental externality. Demonstrates effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of upfront components. Adds to PES and pollution policy literatures; provides actionable insights for program design.

Clear motivation, theory of change, design, and outcome definitions. Figures/tables well-aligned. Balanced discussion of thresholds, inframarginality, and limitations. Strong policy translation without overstating generality.

Pre-registered RCT noted; detailed methods and appendices; remote-sensing approach described. Data/code availability not fully evident in text; satellite model specifics referenced to working paper. Replication feasible with effort but not turnkey.

Targets a major mortality driver in India with global analogs; high external damages, strong policy salience. Practical estimates of costs and lives saved; comparisons to power-plant abatement useful to decision-makers.

Large preregistered US RCT (n=5,243) randomizing UCT amounts, rich admin and survey data, prediction study, careful multiplicity and attrition analyses, and plausible mechanism/model. Results are policy-relevant and overturn optimistic priors. Excellent execution and clarity; minor limits on generalizability and data sharing keep it short of absolute top.

Core claims (no positive average survey effects; spending rose; negative effects concentrated in subjective items; mechanisms most consistent with salience) are precisely stated and strongly supported with ITT, robustness, admin data, BH/WY corrections, and bounding. Cautious on causality for mediation and mechanisms.

Well-powered RCT with unequal arm optimization, preregistration/PAP, indices per Anderson, multiple testing control, extensive attrition diagnostics (Lee/HM bounds, MI), bank data validation, spending categorization, and embedded experiments. Minor risks: selective survey self-report limits; external validity; partial bank coverage.

Advances evidence on UCTs in high-income settings, randomizes amounts, contrasts with expert/lay priors, and offers mechanism plus formal model. Narrows conditions for one-off UCTs to affect well-being and informs cash-plus design. Important null/negative findings with policy salience.

Clear pre-specification, transparent analyses, coherent narrative linking results, mechanisms, and model. Figures/tables are informative. Limits and caveats discussed. A few sections are dense; mechanistic claims appropriately hedged.

Preregistered RCT with PAP; extensive methodological detail; many appendices. Data/code availability likely constrained by privacy/partner data; not all assets may be public. Still above-average transparency and reproducibility.

Directly relevant to UCT policy debates in high-income countries; informs design and expectations for one-off cash vs. cash-plus. Less directly applicable to LMIC UCT settings or long-run outcomes; pandemic context may limit generality.

Large multi-country dataset, preregistered analyses, careful within/between modeling, and clear, tempered claims. Limitations include student-heavy samples, correlational design, single-item trust, and partial openness of data. Solid contribution to social/personality with cross-national scope.

Main claims are specific and cautious; evidence aligns via LMMs and robustness checks. Mediation uses perceived inequality and single-item trust; causal language avoided. Between-country nulls appropriately discussed. Effect sizes modest; some measures subjective.

Preregistration, mixed models, partitioning within/between, controls, and measurement invariance checks are strengths. Weaknesses: correlational design, single-item trust, student convenience samples, potential omitted variables, and partial data availability.

First broad cross-national look at moral expansiveness and societal correlates; links trust and perceived inequality to MES. Advances literature beyond individual differences. Practical pathways hinted but not established causally.
Well-structured narrative, clear hypotheses, transparent reporting of nulls and limitations, figures/tables aid interpretation. Logical consistency between evidence and conclusions.
Preregistration and shared code are strong. Data are available upon request rather than fully open; broad collaboration and supplementary detail help reproducibility.

Findings relevant to understanding societal trust and moral concern globally, with diverse country coverage. However, policy/practice translation is indirect; estimates not readily actionable; samples skewed to students and higher-income contexts.

Clear, policy-relevant synthesis by leading experts, linking theory to a major real-world AMC. Strong practical insights and plausibility, but empirical identification is limited and much evidence is descriptive or comparative. Short P&P format constrains depth and methods.

Claims are stated with caveats and acknowledge lack of a clean counterfactual. Uses descriptive data, comparisons to rotavirus rollout, and cost-effectiveness estimates. Appropriate characterization but modest causal strength.

Summarizes a formal model (developed elsewhere) and applies intuitive welfare and calibration arguments. Limited methodological depth, no new identification or robustness analyses in this short piece.
Synthesizes theory and practice of AMCs, distills design lessons, and informs future applications beyond health. High policy salience and influence despite modest technical novelty.
Well-structured, transparent logic, clear distinctions (tech distant vs close), candid about trade-offs and political economy. Concise communication with useful design guidance.
Relies on public reports and provides online appendix references, but no datasets, code, or replication package. Transparency adequate for a P&P note, limited for replication.
Directly targets global health access and innovation incentives with large potential life-saving impact; lessons generalize to other global priority areas.

High-quality systematic review/meta-analysis with robust frequentist and Bayesian models, extensive sensitivity checks, and clear policy implications.
